company_overview.value_chain_position: Airline operator / service provider (air transportation services)
company_overview.business_description: American Airlines Group Inc. is managed as a single operating segment that provides scheduled air transportation for passengers and cargo, and includes its loyalty program; a leading global airline offering thousands of flights per day to more than 350 destinations in over 60 countries.
company_overview.name: American Airlines Group Inc.

business_segments.description: Passenger revenue from transportation on American and regional flights, including loyalty revenue recognized in passenger revenue for mileage credit redemptions.
business_segments.name: Passenger

business_segments.description: Revenue recognized when American provides cargo transportation.
business_segments.name: Cargo

business_segments.description: Includes loyalty program marketing services (co‑branded credit card and other partners) and other items such as airport clubs, commissions, advertising and vacation‑related services.
business_segments.name: Other

company_owned_facilities.products: Aircraft heavy maintenance, engine overhaul, component work
Operations control, dispatch, flight planning, load planning

contract_manufacturers.notes: AA ordered 85 additional A321neo on 2024-03-04; Airbus notes U.S. production in Mobile, AL.
AA ordered 85 737 MAX 10 and converted 30 MAX 8 to MAX 10 on 2024-03-04.
AA ordered 90 E175 on 2024-03-04 for wholly owned regionals.
Wholly owned regional carrier per AAG disclosure.

critical_suppliers.provides: LEAP-1B engines for Boeing 737 MAX fleet
critical_suppliers.notes: LEAP-1B is sole engine for 737 MAX; AA expanded 737 MAX orders in 2024.
AA selected GEnx-1B in 2018 and signed 20-year TrueChoice Overhaul agreement.
85 additional A321neo ordered 2024-03-04; production in Mobile, AL.

critical_suppliers.provides: 737 MAX and 787 aircraft and OEM parts
E175 regional aircraft and OEM parts

critical_suppliers.notes: AAG risk factor mentions cessation of Bombardier regional production.
Long-term hosted reservation system renewed Dec 10 2024.
Wi-Fi on >900 mainline aircraft; ad-sponsored rollout 2024-2026.
Dual-sourced with Viasat; installations announced Mar 20 2024.

supplier_concentration.concentration_notes: The supply base is concentrated among a few aircraft and engine OEMs (Airbus, Boeing, Embraer; CFM/GE). American discloses dependence on a limited number of suppliers and that some aircraft/engines/parts are sourced outside the U.S. Precise supplier geography percentages are not disclosed.

supply_corridors.flow_description: Airframes assembled at Airbus’s Mobile, Alabama plant are delivered to American’s U.S. operating bases, reducing trans‑Atlantic logistics exposure.
Boeing‑manufactured 737 and 787 aircraft are shipped from U.S. factories to American’s base maintenance locations across the United States.
Components and sub‑assemblies for Airbus aircraft and CFM engines produced in Europe are shipped to U.S. assembly lines and maintenance facilities.
Embraer delivers E175 regional jets and spare parts from Brazil to American’s regional subsidiaries in the United States.

supply_chain_initiatives.purpose: Expand and modernize base maintenance, add wide‑body capable hangar and upgrade infrastructure to insource more work and improve reliability
Grow and improve Tulsa base and engine repair/overhaul capacity; hire additional maintenance staff
supply_chain_initiatives.initiative: $22M Oklahoma grant for Tulsa enhancements + engine shop investment

supply_chain_initiatives.purpose: Increase in‑house heavy maintenance capacity and preserve long‑term capability
supply_chain_initiatives.initiative: Add heavy check lines + ~500 new maintenance jobs (CLT, PIT, TUL)

supply_chain_initiatives.purpose: Maintain a balanced multi‑OEM orderbook to support capacity flexibility and reduce concentration risk
Standardize connectivity across fleet and secure long‑term vendor partnerships

segment_mix.notes: B2B includes loyalty marketing services, cargo, and estimated managed corporate/SMB passenger revenue; B2G is a small estimated share; B2C is the residual consumer/leisure passenger revenue.

customer_concentration.disclosure_notes: Diversified, atomized customer base (226 M passengers in 2024). 10‑K discloses large loyalty partners (Citi/Barclays) but does not attribute ≥10 % of total revenue to any single customer.

top_customers.notes: Largest co‑brand partner; Dec 2024 announcement of 10‑year exclusive U.S. issuer agreement starting 2026; estimate reflects share of loyalty marketing services revenue.
top_customers.name: Citibank N.A.

top_customers.notes: Co‑brand partner through 2025; smaller share than Citi.
top_customers.name: Barclays US

top_customers.notes: Low single‑digit share typical for gov’t travel/military/mail.
top_customers.name: U.S. Government (City Pair / DoD / mail & charters)

industry_exposure.notes: Estimated exposure based on recovered managed business and premium travel demand.
Exposure driven by co‑branded credit card partnerships and loyalty program revenue.
Typical enterprise travel vertical for network carriers; no specific disclosure.
Aligned with the B2G estimate; includes federal travel and charters.
Estimated based on broader business travel normalization.

customer_characteristics.geographic_notes: 2024 passenger revenue by region: Domestic $35,336 m (~71% of passenger revenue), Latin America $6,560 m, Atlantic $6,445 m, Pacific $1,245 m.
customer_characteristics.typical_contract_length: Co‑brand credit card: 10‑year agreement announced 2024‑12‑05 (effective 2026). Mileage‑credit partner contracts: remaining terms generally 1‑10 years as of 2024‑12‑31. Corporate/TMC agreements: multi‑year, specific terms not disclosed.
customer_characteristics.recurring_vs_transactional: Recurring: Loyalty marketing services under multi‑year partner and co‑brand agreements; Transactional: Passenger tickets and cargo revenue recognized when transportation is provided.

policy_constraints.policy_description: BIS advanced computing and semiconductor manufacturing export controls, including controls on advanced computing ICs, related computers, and certain semiconductor manufacturing items; revises October 7, 2022 controls.
policy_constraints.issuing_authority: U.S. Department of Commerce, Bureau of Industry and Security (BIS)

policy_constraints.policy_description: FAA NOTAM KICZ A0004/22 prohibits U.S. civil flight operations in all FIRs managed by Ukraine; FAA removed obsolete SFAR No. 113 but NOTAM restrictions remain.
affected_regions: Ukraine FIRs: Lviv (UKLV), Kyiv (UKBV), Dnipro (UKDV), Simferopol (UKFV), Odesa (UKOV), Kyiv UIR (UKBU)

policy_constraints.policy_description: U.S. orders blocking Russian aircraft from entering/using all U.S. domestic airspace.
affected_product_categories: Operations of aircraft owned/operated/controlled by persons connected with Russia

policy_constraints.policy_description: EU ban requiring Member States to deny landing, takeoff, or overflight to Russian air carriers, Russian-registered aircraft, and non‑Russian registered aircraft owned/chartered/controlled by Russian persons.
UK Air Navigation (Restriction of Flying) (Russian Aircraft) Regulations 2022 – prohibition on Russian aircraft flying in UK airspace; strengthened ban and trade sanctions announced 2022-03-09.
affected_product_categories: Russian-owned/chartered/operated or registered aircraft; flights to/from Russian aerodromes (per amendment)

policy_constraints.policy_description: U.S.-EU cooperative framework suspending tariffs related to the Large Civil Aircraft dispute for five years.
policy_constraints.issuing_authority: Office of the U.S. Trade Representative (USTR) / European Commission
affected_product_categories: Large civil aircraft and related products

regional_demand_signals.description: First 7 AI Factories selected; –1.5 billion initial investment combining EU and national funds; deployments across multiple Member States.
Overall investments in supercomputing infrastructures and AI Factories in the EU to reach –10 billion over 2021–2027.

regional_demand_signals.timeframe: Running from summer 2024 (Isambard–AI); Dawn operational by end–2023 per announcement
regional_demand_signals.description: 300m AIRR to build two AI supercomputers; additional 500m AI compute over two years; HPE selected supplier for Isambard–AI; Dawn delivered with Dell/Intel/StackHPC.
regional_demand_signals.initiator: UK Government (DSIT); UKRI; University of Bristol; University of Cambridge; industry partners

regional_demand_signals.timeframe: Pilot in 2024 with further calls in spring 2024; ongoing
regional_demand_signals.description: NAIRR pilot launched to provide access to advanced computing, datasets, models, software, training and user support to U.S. researchers and educators; initial allocations and subsequent calls in 2024.
regional_demand_signals.signal_type: National AI research compute/data access (NAIRR pilot)
regional_demand_signals.initiator: U.S. National Science Foundation (NSF) with federal and private partners

competitor_factual_moves.description: DOT approved United to launch three weekly LAX–PEK flights; conditions included inauguration by 2025-05-11.
competitor_factual_moves.move_type: route authorization/expansion under DOT-managed U.S.–China frequencies

competitor_factual_moves.description: United announced resumption/increase of daily SFO–PVG from 2023-10-01 and daily SFO–PEK starting November 2023, in context of DOT frequency adjustments.
Delta announced resumption to daily SEA–PVG and 3x weekly DTW–PVG starting 2023-10-29.

factual_actions.description: USDOT noted American began operating two additional roundtrip weekly flights to Shanghai from Texas in March 2023 following easing of PRC restrictions.
